adjective.description: Expected at or planned for at a certain time.
examples: talks are due to adjourn tomorrow

adjective.description: Of the proper quality or extent; adequate.
examples: driving without due care and attention

noun.description: A person's right; what is owed to someone.
examples: he attracts more criticism than is his due
he had paid union dues for years

adverb.description: (with reference to a point of the compass) exactly; directly.
examples: we'll head due south again on the same road

phrases: unemployment due to automation will grow steadily
She also found signs of hypoxic damage to nerve cells due to lack of oxygen before death.
The delay was due to a lack of scaffolding.
This could be due to apathy on the part of locals or lack of knowledge that they exist.
This increase and subsequent decrease are likely due, in part, to changes in freedoms and responsibilities.
origin: Middle English (in the sense payable): from Old French deu owed, based on Latin debitus owed, from debere owe.
